subject: You Are Invited! The Future of Foreign Aid: An Evening with Pangea Giving
body:
The Future of Foreign Aid: 
An Evening with Pangea Giving
Join fellow Pangea Giving members for a meaningful evening of connection, dialogue, and shared purpose.
Our featured guest speaker, 
Dr. James Pfeiffer
, Professor of Global Health and Anthropology at the University of Washington, will draw from his extensive experience with USAID to explore the evolution of U.S. foreign assistance, how aid is delivered today, and ideas for rethinking the role of governments in global development. He’ll also examine how these shifts are impacting our local partners around the world. 
Enjoy updates from Pangea Pod Chairs on the work of our partners in the field, and connect with fellow members. Food and drinks will be provided.

Pangea and GlobalWA members

subject: GlobalWA blog: Communications in Chaotic Times
body:
March 17, 2025
 
Dear Grace,
 
On February 26, 2025, GlobalWA’s Communications Collective held a closed-door webinar for our members. As part of the registration, we asked key questions to provide us with insights into the main challenges our members were facing related to current executive orders to help us tune our discussion. We held an active, participatory 75-minute session primarily focused on Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accessibility (DEIA) in communications in the current political environment, yet nearly all of the takeaways apply to any communications. 
To inform and guide the dialogue, we invited communications experts Mikki Dragoo, Partner at 
Stronger Stories
, and Matthew Tsang, Brand Director and Co-founder of 
AndHumanity
. Stronger Stories is a strategic and creative consultancy that uses the power of story to build belief in good ideas. AndHumanity is an integrated inclusive marketing and communications agency with the core purpose of serving people-first brands.
 
Communications in Chaotic Times
 
 
This article is a recap of the discussions including 
resources 
and 
guidance
. 
We hope you will find this useful for your organization's communications strategies and tactics.
We are stronger together. Photo: Tumisu/Pixabay
 
Also...
We've continue to update out recently
 published 
resources document
 to help global development organizations and peoples recently laid off due to the recent executive orders. 
 
This document contains jobs, alternative funding sources, thought pieces how to navigate these changes, paths for advocacy, relevant events, analyses and insights from across media, and more:
 
Resources for Global Development Organizations 2025
 
Please share, and please send any resources you think the community may find helpful that we can add to the list to 
comms@globalwa.org
.

subject: Upcoming GlobalWA Events
body:
Upcoming GlobalWA Events
 
 
State of the Sector: 
Final Mile Meeting with Kyle House
With the immense and immediate crisis unfolding for the US foreign assistance community, it would be remiss not to spend our time now to continue to gain better understanding of the applications of the Presidential executive orders and how we can best engage to find a return to the bipartisan support to the soft diplomacy work that has helped fund our efforts in the past. Most of us have been impacted by funding freezes, stop work orders, and requirements to return workers deployed overseas. Most have also likely spent time with legal counsel just to get paid for work performed. To give a well-rounded perspective of the current environment’s challenges, Global Washington and Logenix International are very grateful to welcome 
Porter DeLaney
 of 
Kyle House
 to present for us on Thursday, March 13th.

Credit union leaders consistently navigate a rapidly evolving landscape, where diverse, future members expect seamless digital experiences. CRM systems and strong digital infrastructures are key to meeting these rising expectations. Join us for an engaging webinar featuring:

subject: Pangea Giving February 2025 Update
body:
February 2025
 
Dear GlobalWA and Pangea Community, 
As we step into the new year, we want to take a moment to celebrate the incredible work Pangea and our grant partners are doing. Through your dedication and support, we continue to champion grassroots organizations that are driving change in their communities, even in the face of mounting challenges. 
The global political landscape is shifting in ways that have put immense pressure on civil society organizations, including many of our partners. Yet, their resilience is unwavering. Their work—whether advancing human rights, advocating for marginalized communities, or building sustainable solutions—remains vital. And through Pangea, we stand with them, ensuring they have the resources and support to navigate these turbulent times. 
Your engagement has made a tangible impact. Our 2024 annual grant appeal raised 
$39,108
, a 
71.5%
 increase from last year! This generosity reflects the deep commitment of our community to the work our partners do every day. 
January and February have been key planning months for Global Washington. We’ve been holding in-depth conversations with key members of the Pangea and Global Washington communities, discussing how to strengthen and grow Pangea in the years ahead. These discussions have been energizing, and we are excited about the ideas emerging as we approach the new fiscal year in April. 
Thank you for being part of this journey. Your support, insight, and passion for global change are what make Pangea strong. We look forward to sharing more updates soon. 
With gratitude, 
Elizabeth Stokely (Executive Director) and Pratima Stanton (Program Director) 
 
* * * * * * * 
Donate to Pangea Giving
We are deeply grateful for every contribution that helps sustain our program and empowers our grassroots partners. 
Learn more about Pangea Giving
.
 
Save the Date! 
Pangea Giving Member Gathering
 
Join fellow Pangea Giving members—now a program of Global Washington—for an evening of connection and conversation. Enjoy the chance to mingle, hear updates from Pangea Chairs on the work of our partners in the field, and stay tuned for an exciting guest speaker announcement! 
 
April 4th, 3-5 PM
Space is limited so register soon:
Register Here
Food and drinks will be provided.
 
ForeignAid Bridge Fund
To support efforts against the recent drastic reductions in foreign aid by the government, please consider donating to the 
ForeignAid Bridge Fund
.
 
https://www.foreignaidbridgefund.org/
 
Pod Updates
The grant cycle is officially underway, and Pod meetings are in full swing! We encourage all members to take part in these important discussions. If you’d like to join a Pod or need more information, please email 
pangea@globalwa.org
. 
Meeting with Voces y Manos. 
Site Visit to Guatemala
Last October, Pangea members Betsy Hale, Janet Pearson, and Diane Logan traveled to Guatemala as part of its new partner search process. They had the opportunity to meet with 
Voces y Manos
, a new Latin America pod grant recipient, and visit other existing partners in the region. You can read their 
full report here
. 
 
Welcome New Member!
Jim McCullagh
: Jim lives in the Blue Ridge neighborhood of north Seattle with his wife, Angie. They have two children, a son and a daughter, who are both undergraduates at UW. He was a partner at a large law firm for 20 years before retiring at the end of 2019. Before attending law school, he worked as a marine biologist in Santa Barbara, California, for a little over ten years. Now, he spends his time on home improvement projects, traveling, and enjoying the outdoors through hiking and backpacking. He recently learned about giving circles and looks forward to learning more about and contributing to the worthwhile projects supported by Pangea Giving.   
Jim McCullagh
 
Other Events
 
International Women's Day at the Gates Discovery Center:
 Global Washington is partnering with the Gates Discovery Center. Celebrate International Women’s Day with @DiscoverGates on March 5 to hear from Djaïli Amadou Amal, renowned Cameroonian writer, activist, and UNICEF Ambassador—plus enjoy music by a local DJ and contemporary African appetizers! 
Djaïli draws from her lived experiences to share powerful stories that highlight the resilience of women navigating cultural and societal barriers. 
The event will be moderated by Sybil Chidiac, Senior Program Officer for Women’s Economic Empowerment and Gender Equality at the Gates Foundation. Program in French with English interpretation. #IWD2025 
Free to attend! RSVP

body:
Read on web
 | 
Unsubscribe

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
2025-02-21
Expanded Virtual Offerings to Support Credit Union Professionals Worldwide
Choose from four 2025 WOCCU Workshop programs
MADISON, Wis.— The World Council of Credit Unions (WOCCU) is proud to offer a dynamic series of 
virtual workshops
 designed to equip credit union professionals with the knowledge, skills and tools needed to drive innovation and excellence in the financial cooperative sector.
WOCCU Workshops provide interactive learning experiences, featuring global industry experts who lead discussions on key trends, best practices and practical strategies that credit unions can implement immediately. These sessions foster collaboration among professionals from around the world, ensuring that participants gain valuable insights tailored to the unique challenges and opportunities within the credit union movement. To accommodate credit union professionals in different time zones, workshops are offered at various times throughout the year.
Upcoming Workshops Include:
Digital Sustainability: Strategies and Tools for Credit Unions – Tuesday, March 11
th
 from 6:00pm – 8:30pm
Banking in the Age of Generative AI – Thursday May 1 from 10:00am – 1:00pm CT
Marketing the Mission – Connecting Purpose to Growth – Tuesday, August 19
th
 from 9:00am - 11:30am CT
Small Credit Union Workshop – Date and Time To Be Determined
"WOCCU’s virtual workshops provide an accessible and affordable way for credit union professionals to advance their expertise without the need for travel. Each session is designed to be highly engaging, featuring real-world case studies, interactive discussions, and actionable takeaways," said Kassandra Schroeder, WOCCU Virtual Engagements and Special Events Manager.
Attendees are eligible for Continuing Professional Education (CPE) credits by attending. For more information and to register for an upcoming workshop, visit 
www.woccu.org/workshops
.
World Council of Credit Unions (WOCCU) is the apex association for credit unions and other global financial cooperatives. World Council promotes the sustainable development of credit unions and other financial cooperatives around the world to empower people through access to high quality and affordable financial services. World Council advocates on behalf of the global credit union system before international organizations and works with national governments to improve legislation and regulation. Its technical assistance programs introduce new tools and technologies to strengthen credit unions' financial performance and increase their outreach.
World Council has implemented 300+ technical assistance programs in 90 countries. Worldwide, 74,634 credit unions in 104 countries serve 411 million people. Learn more about World Council's impact around the world at 
www.woccu.org
.

subject: February 2025 Issue Campaign: Gender Equality
body:
February 2025 Issue Campaign: Gender Equality
Table of Contents
Issue Brief
Organization Profile
Goalmaker Spotlight
Member Blogs
Welcome New Members
GlobalWA Events
Community Events
Careers
Dear Grace,
 
The world is not on track to achieve gender equality by 2030. In practical terms, what does this mean? According to the UN, if current trends continue, over 340 million women and girls will live in extreme poverty by 2030. At the current rate, it will take 300 years to end child marriage, 286 years to change discriminatory laws, and 140 years to achieve equal representation in workplace leadership.
 
On the flip side, it is 
estimated
 that closing the gender gap would expand the global economy by $7T USD. Education plays a key role in closing the gap. Studies show that educating girls leads to higher wages, improved health outcomes, and stronger economies. Additionally, countries with higher levels of gender equality experience 
lower rates of conflict
 and greater political stability.
 
 
In these rapidly shifting times for international development, I am inspired by the hard work and dedication of GlobalWA members. The Issue Brief below highlights how our member organizations are closing the gender gap with timely, strategic, and forward-thinking interventions.
 
Sincerely,
Elizabeth Stokely,
Executive Director
 
 
ISSUE BRIEF
Gender Equality Proves Indispensable to Global Development
 
Sustainable Development Goal 5 stands as a cornerstone of global progress, championing gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls worldwide. Recognizing that gender equality is not only a fundamental human right, but a critical driver of peace, prosperity, and sustainability, the tenets of SDG 5 address the systemic barriers that hinder women and girls from fully participating in society.
 
Continue ››
 
ORGANIZATION PROFILE
Sustaining Movements, Securing Rights: CAMY Fund’s Decade of Empowering Feminist Youth-Led Change
 
Anniversaries are a perfect time to reflect upon where you’ve been, and where you’re going.
 
After mobilizing more than $6 million in funding to support over 100 youth-led organizations across Central America and Mexico, the Central America Youth Fund (CAMY Fund), a program of the 
Seattle International Foundation 
 (SIF), is celebrating their tenth anniversary—and looking ahead to what’s next.
Continue ››
 
GOALMAKER SPOTLIGHT
Alice Lemunu – VOCFINU
 
Voices of Children’s Faith in Northern Uganda, or VOCFINU, a GlobalWA member since 2020, is dedicated to uplifting Northern Uganda's vulnerable populations, especially children, women, and adolescents affected by poverty and post-war hardships. Their holistic approach addresses the immediate needs of education, healthcare, and skills development to create pathways out of poverty and toward sustainable, empowered communities.
 
Continue ››

WELCOME NEW MEMBERS
Please welcome our newest Global Washington members. Take a moment to familiarize yourself with their work and consider opportunities for support and collaboration!
AndHumanity
AndHumanity is an integrated inclusive marketing and communications agency with the core purpose of serving people-first brands. Since its origin, AndHumanity has partnered with brave, compassionate, and future thinking leaders across the globe, with notable clients like Arc’teryx, Henkel, TELUS, Telefilm Canada, ASML, and more. It was founded by siblings Matthew and Tammy Tsang - international award-winning marketers - who wanted to be seen in their work, and to stop perpetuating stereotypes and harm within the industry. They wanted to combine their love of marketing with their desire to ensure their children would see themselves represented in the media sphere. 
andhumanity.co
  
Friends of WPC Nepal
Friends of WPC Nepal is a fundraising organization that seeks to prevent human trafficking as well as protect and empower at-risk women and children in Nepal through awareness programs, education scholarships, job training, and the Safe home. 
friendsofwpcnepal.org
Milkah Kihunah Consulting
Dedicated Program Manager and Advocacy Specialist with 15+ years of experience designing and implementing initiatives to promote gender equality, social inclusion, and community-led development while driving policy change. Passionate about empowering women, young people, and vulnerable groups to access essential resources, including education, economic opportunities, health and social support. 
Milkah Kihunah | LinkedIn
 
myAgro
myAgro is a rapidly growing 501(c)(3) non-profit organization dedicated to empowering smallholder farmers in West Africa.  myAgro offers a mobile layaway platform that allows farmers to save for agricultural inputs in small increments, and then deliver high-quality agricultural products and corresponding training to improve farmers’ yields. With its innovative model and commitment to sustainable agriculture, myAgro aims to reach and support one million smallholder farmers by 2027. 
MyAgro
 
Save the Children
Save the Children believes every child deserves a future. In United States and around the world, we do whatever it takes – every day and in times of crisis – so children can fulfill their rights to a healthy start in life, the opportunity to learn and protection from harm. With over 100 years of expertise, we are the world’s first and leading independent children’s organization – transforming lives and the future we share. 
savethechildren.org
 
University of Washington School of Law - Sustainable International Development Graduate Program
The UW Law Sustainable International Development (SID) Program trains lawyers to address interrelated global challenges and to advance law and policy frameworks that help people thrive within the ecological limits of our planet. 
law.uw.edu/academics/llm/sustainable-development

subject: Reminder: GlobalWA event, Feb 26: Communications in Chaotic Times
body:
February 20, 2025
 
Dear Grace,
 
Simply a REMINDER of our Zoom event for GlobalWA Members:
Feb. 26, 9:00 AM - 10:15 AM PST / 12:00 PM - 1:15 PM EST
Communications in Chaotic Times 
 
DETAILS:
Presented by GlobalWA’s 
Communications Collective
 with members, 
Stronger Stories
 and 
AndHumanity
.  
What can we say? What 
should 
we say? And who should we be saying it to? A change in the White House has brought a flood of executive orders and shaken perceived norms around inclusion, sustainability, humanitarian aid and progressive systems change. It’s left many GlobalWA members in an existential crisis – and wondering, where do we go now? 
Based on our conviction that our community makes us stronger, GlobalWA is providing a space for GlobalWA members to explore their challenges and support each other through this chaotic and uncertain inflection point.  
Join us for an interactive, member-driven session, co-facilitated by DEI marketing and communications experts at AndHumanity and the narrative strategists at Stronger Stories. It will be an off-the-record space for candid conversations, shared challenges, and practical tools to help members find a path forward, together. 
WHAT:
 Virtual (Zoom) meeting 
DATE:
 February 26
TIME:
 9:00 - 10:15 AM PST / 12:00 - 1:15 PM EST
 
Read more:
 
Communications in Chaotic Times

 This event is for any employee of a verified GlobalWA member - please share with your member organization colleagues wherever they may reside.

body:

Dear Grace,
 
We JUST heard about a 
U.S. State Department
 public listening session on foreign assistance, and you must 
RSVP today by 2pm PT
 if you'd like to join. Here are the details:
* * * * *
 
You are invited to join a Foreign Assistance Listening Session 
On How to Use U.S. Foreign Assistance to Make America Safer, Stronger, and More Prosperous  
On Friday, February 14, 2:00 p.m. – 4:00 p.m EST (11am-1pm PT)
Hosted virtually by the U.S. Department of State 
We look forward to your feedback and new ideas to ensure that U.S. foreign assistance makes America safer, stronger, and more prosperous, and delivers measurable benefits to the American people. 
RSVP 
Here
 by February 12 at 5PM EST (2pm PT)
All attendees must complete the linked RSVP form by 5 p.m. on February 12. You will receive a link to join virtually after registration.

fab@state.gov

subject: A Critical Moment for Global Engagement and Humanitarian Assistance
body:
January 30, 2025
 
Dear Grace,
 
We are reaching out at a time of unprecedented uncertainty for the global development and humanitarian sectors. Recent executive orders from the U.S. administration have imposed a freeze on foreign aid, halted numerous federal grants, withdrawn from international environmental commitments, and introduced significant restrictions on diversity, equity, inclusion, and accessibility initiatives. These actions have immediate and devastating implications for our collective work to improve lives and strengthen communities around the world.
 
 
This abrupt policy shift has placed many of our members in crisis. The freeze on USAID funding and other federal grants has triggered 
stop-work orders across critical programs
, jeopardizing food security, global health initiatives, gender equity projects, and climate resilience efforts. From emergency relief operations in conflict zones to long-term development projects that foster sustainable economic growth, these funding cuts are already forcing difficult decisions—shutting down programs, laying off staff, and leaving vulnerable populations without essential services.
 
 
Immediate Impact on Our Members
 
The consequences of these executive orders are and will be deeply felt across Global Washington’s network:
 
Humanitarian and development programs are grinding to a halt.
 USAID’s funding freeze, coupled with an opaque review process, has left organizations scrambling to secure alternative funding or suspend operations altogether. This affects everything from maternal and child health programs to anti-poverty initiatives and refugee assistance.
Environmental and climate action efforts are in jeopardy.
 The U.S. withdrawal from international agreements and funding freezes on environmental programs severely undermine the fight against climate change, disproportionately impacting communities most vulnerable to its effects.
Inclusive development efforts are under threat.
 Restrictions on diversity, equity, inclusion and accessibility funding risk rolling back hard-won progress in equity-driven global development, particularly for women, Indigenous communities, and other historically marginalized groups.
For many of our members, this freeze is not just a bureaucratic hurdle—it is an existential crisis. Organizations that have spent years building trust and impact in communities worldwide now face the prospect of shuttering their doors, leaving millions without the support they rely on.
 
What Comes Next?
 
This is not a moment for silence. We must act swiftly and decisively to protect the progress we have made and advocate for the restoration of essential funding. We urge those in the development sector to:
 
Join us for a closed-door CEO discussion. 
We will be convening a members-only CEO roundtable about the executive orders in the coming weeks. Look out for an invitation to hear from other leaders, share insights, ask questions, and coordinate our collective response.
Attend the next GlobalWA Communications Collective event. 
Our upcoming members-only learning session will ground attendees in inclusive marketing and communications for chaotic times.
Engage with policymakers.
 Advocate for the immediate reinstatement of critical foreign aid and development funding. Contact your representatives and make clear the human cost of these decisions. This 
initiative
 is documenting the impact of the foreign aid stop work order. 
Mobilize alternative funding.
 We call on philanthropic foundations, private sector leaders, and global donors to fill funding gaps created by this freeze. Increased private sector engagement will be essential in sustaining programs.
Amplify the urgency.
 Share this message within your networks to ensure that the full impact of these policies is widely understood and that the most affected voices are heard.
Our Commitment Moving Forward
 
Despite these challenges, we remain steadfast in our mission to support a globally engaged Washington state and to advance solutions that foster equity, sustainability, and human dignity worldwide. We, the global development community, 
believe in our shared humanity
 and understand that a retreat from international assistance hurts us all.
  
As we navigate this uncertain landscape, we will continue to provide resources and opportunities for collective action. We urge you to stay engaged, stand in solidarity with affected organizations and with one another, and advocate for the restoration of U.S. leadership in global development.
 
Please do not hesitate to contact us at 
info@globalwa.org
.
 
In partnership and solidarity,
Elizabeth Stokely
Executive Director, Global Washington

subject: GlobalWA 2024 Year in Review
body:
2024 Year in Review
 
2024 was a year of transformation and progress—for our organization, our member network, and the global development community at large.
In the face of unprecedented change, many organizations demonstrated unrelenting resilience, adapting strategies and innovating to deliver social and environmental impact. Our members adapted to climate change and provided new agricultural practices and programs. Some created new economic opportunities for their communities, while others educated the new workforce for today’s economy. Others enhanced their refugee and IDP resettlement and support programs, and many embraced technologies like artificial intelligence to expand their impact. 
As we step into 2025, we are committed to supporting and amplifying this vital work through communities of practice, dynamic events, and new opportunities for connection.
Read on for highlights from 2024 and a preview of what’s to come. Together, let’s create a positive impact in 2025!
Elizabeth Stokely
Executive Director

subject: Pangea Giving Winter 2024 Update
body:
December 2024
 
Dear GlobalWA and Pangea Community! 
As we wrap up a busy and exciting fall, I am thrilled to share some highlights and updates from Pangea Giving. This season has been filled with energy and momentum—from amplifying grassroots voices at the 
Goalmakers Conference
 to welcoming new connections and partnerships. It has been truly inspiring to see the power of our community in action.  
I’m delighted to report that our annual appeal is off to an incredible start, already surpassing last year’s total. This success is a testament to the dedication and generosity of our community. Your support ensures we’re well-positioned for the upcoming 2025 grant cycle and prepared to make an even greater impact. 
If you haven’t had a chance to contribute yet, we warmly invite you to donate 
here
. 100% of your donation goes directly to the 2025 Grant Pool, where it will make a meaningful and lasting difference for the grassroots organizations we proudly support. 
Looking ahead, we are gearing up for an exciting few months. January will bring the start of our pod meetings, where members can dive deep into the grantmaking process. We’re also exploring potential site visits and new opportunities to connect and learn together as a community. Your involvement and commitment continue to drive meaningful change, and we can’t thank you enough for your support. 
 
With gratitude, 
 
Elizabeth Stokely, 
Executive Director, & Pratima Stanton, Programs Director
Solidarity Eden Foundation, Uganda, Executive Director, Jules Mayele. 
AMPLIFYING LOCAL VOICES AT GOALMAKERS 2024
 
Pangea Giving proudly showcased powerful 
voices from the field
 at this year’s Goalmakers Conference through both virtual and in-person activities: 
Virtual Session
: We shared inspiring stories of grassroots change through videos and live discussions: 
Women Peacemakers, Cambodia – Celebrating peacebuilding and empowerment.
Voces y Manos, Latin America – Reviving ancestral agricultural practices through agroecology.
Solidarity Eden Foundation, Uganda – Featuring 
The Tegere Story
 video and a live Q&A with Executive Director Jules Mayele. 
Special Guests
 Jules Mayele from Uganda and longtime partner Joshua Machinga from Kenya offered deep insights into the successes and challenges of grassroots development. The session drew 70 participants and highlighted the power of local voices. Watch the recording here: 
Goalmakers 2024 Dec. 3rd - Pangea Lunch and Learn and Closing Remarks.
 
 
Common Ground for Africa, Kenya, Executive Director, Joshua Machinga. 
In-person Engagement
: Pangea’s table at the conference welcomed many visitors, with six individuals signing up to learn more about our work.
Member Celebration Spotlight:
 During the conference’s most-attended lunch session, Anne Sivley, Pangea Advisory Council Member and GlobalWA Board Member, delivered an inspiring speech about Pangea’s mission and impact. Anne stepped in seamlessly when visa delays prevented Joshua Machinga from attending. 
The Pangea table at the in-person day of Goalmakers 2024 was visited by many.
Anne Sivley, Pangea Advisory Council Member and GlobalWA Board Member
 
EXCITING NEWS
 
Welcoming Voces y Manos as Our New LA Pod Partner for 2024 
We’re delighted to announce 
Voces y Manos
 as our new Latin America pod partner for the 2024 grant cycle! This inspiring organization works to foster buen vivir—a concept of “good living”—by empowering communities through social leadership and promoting ancestral agroecological practices that restore harmony between generations and the natural world.  
Project Goal:
 Voces y Manos focuses on reviving ancestral agricultural practices and passing this vital knowledge to primary school children in the rural area of Rabinal, Baja Verapaz, Guatemala. We were proud to contribute $6,000 to support this transformative work. 
Guatemala site visit with Taa' P'it.
Site Visit to Guatemala
 
In October, Pangea members Betsy Hale, Janet Pearson, and Diane Logan traveled to Guatemala as part of our partner search process. They had the opportunity to meet with Voces y Manos and visit other existing partners in the region, such as Taa' P'it. Trip report coming soon!
 
WHAT'S AHEAD
 
January Pod Meetings and Grant Cycle 
Mark your calendars! January kicks off our upcoming pod meetings as we prepare for the 2024 grant cycle. These meetings are a great opportunity to:
Learn more about our partners and their work.
Engage with fellow members and contribute to our grant decision process.
Stay tuned for meeting details and how you can get involved! 
 
THANK YOU!
Your support is the driving force behind everything we do. Together, we’re empowering grassroots leaders and fostering lasting change in communities around the world. 
If you’re interested in learning more, attending a pod meeting, or deepening your involvement, we’d love to hear from you! This holiday season, consider sharing Pangea’s mission with friends and family—every connection helps grow our impact. 
For more information on membership, how to donate to our Pangea Grant Pool, and how to get involved, 
visit us here
.

subject: 2025 Global Philanthropy Guide has been published!
body:
2025 Global Philanthropy Guide
 
We are very excited to announce we have published our 2025 Global Philanthropy Guide.
 
Our focus in this year's guide is 
refugees
. Forcibly displaced persons topped over 120,000,000 this year - one in every 69 people, or 1.5 per cent of the entire world’s population, is now forcibly displaced. This is nearly double the 1 in 125 people who were displaced a decade ago. 
Methods to help refugees and internally displaced persons are many, and our members exemplify solid, working solutions.
In the 
2025 Global Philanthropy Guide
, we selected key data, stories, blogs, and interviews to help you understand the situation and the solutions being deployed.
Read about:
 
Global Trends data from 
UNHCR, the UN Refugee Agency
Emtithal Mahmoud
, UNHCR Global Goodwill Ambassador, and former Sudanese refugee
CARE
 and how they are responding to the crisis of internally displaced people in Gaza, Ukraine, and other countries
Global Communities
 and their work protecting child refugees and IDPs from Syria and Ukraine
Global Mentorship Initiative
 and how they are helping refugees with their new lives with impact sourcing, and their wonderful partnership with 
USA for UNHCR
 
International Rescue Committee
 and the programs they have employed to support refugees in Washington State
Oxfam
 and how they support refugees (since their inception in 1942) via an interview with their Humanitarian Director
Also included:
A complete guide to our members who work on social and environmental impact issues across the globe
A full list of 
Pangea Giving
's 16 grant partners across Latin America, Southeast Asia, and East Africa - Pangea is a giving circle program of GlobalWA
Read, download, reference, share:
 
2025 Global Philanthropy Guide
Produced in partnership with 
Seattle Foundation.

subject: Pangea Giving: Together, We Can Transform Lives
body:
Hello, Changemaker! 
 
Pangea Giving
 is a giving circle that provides our members direct, thoughtful, and effective ways to engage in trust-based partnerships with grassroots organizations in the Global South to improve the quality of life in their communities. 
We invite you to join us! 
As a member of Pangea, you become an active partner in creating meaningful change, uniting with like-minded philanthropists to amplify their collective impact 
and empower communities to thrive.
YES, I WANT TO BE A MEMBER
Pangea site visits in East Africa, Southeast Asia, and Latin America.
 
Help Pangea continue to empower communities by
giving to the Pangea Grant pool!
 
Please consider providing a tax-deductible donation to directly help grassroots organizations in 
Latin America
, 
Southeast Asia
, and 
East Africa
.  
YES, I WANT TO DONATE
Make an immediate impact.
100% of donations are distributed to our grant partners.
 
Here's how your contribution will make a difference:
 
East Africa:
 Our partners in East Africa are transforming lives by empowering women and youth, supporting refugees, and advancing environmental resilience. From strengthening women’s financial independence in Uganda to fostering leadership and food security in Kenya, they are building stronger, more resilient communities. Through agricultural and tech-based training, they’re creating lasting economic opportunities and equipping the next generation with skills for a sustainable future.   
Children in vocational school program - formerly street kids.
Southeast Asia:
 Pangea grantees across Asia are empowering indigenous women and youth, uplifting refugees, and championing environmental justice. From strengthening women's networks and fostering youth leadership in Cambodia, to supporting Myanmar refugees in Thailand, and training advocates for sustainable change in Laos and Myanmar, our partners are creating lasting impact. During a 
recent site visit
, our Asia Pod members were deeply inspired by the resilience and transformative work they witnessed firsthand.   
Planning with FORTUNE, Thailand.
Latin America:
 Our partners are transforming lives by advancing women’s empowerment, indigenous rights, and environmental justice. From essential education in Guatemala to reproductive health advocacy in Mexico, and from supporting Tzutujil Maya women in nutrition and sustainability to defending indigenous land rights, their impact is profound. With the addition of our new partner, Voces y Manos, identified by a successful site visit this year, we’re deepening our commitment to sustainable, community-driven change.   
Site visit, Guatemala.
 
As 2024 draws to a close, we invite you to reflect on the resilience of our partners, how we want to impact the future, and consider a generous donation to our Annual Fund. Together, we can continue creating sustainable change in 2025 and beyond.  
DONATE TODAY
Learn more about Pangea Giving

subject: Webinar: Transforming Credit Unions: Achieving ORM Maturity in the Digital Age
body:
Read on web
 | 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent to: g.vottero@lcwmail.com
 
Webinar: 
Transforming Credit Unions: Achieving ORM Maturity in the Digital Age
When: Friday, December 13 at 10:00 am CT
Esta sesión también estará disponible en español.
Are you ready to transform your credit union’s approach to Operational Risk Management (ORM)?
Join us for an exclusive webinar where we’ll explore the key facts, strategies, and real-world examples that can help your organization navigate ORM with confidence and precision.
In this session, you’ll discover:
Understanding ORM Maturity
: What it is and why it’s essential in today’s digital landscape.
ABC Credit Union’s Journey
: A hypothetical success story illustrating the path from challenges to a thriving ORM culture.
Achieving the Utopian ORM Model
: How to build a future-ready framework and implement actionable steps for long-term success.
This session is presented by:
Gunpreet Kaur
Enterprise Risk Manager
Khalsa Credit Union
Canada
World Council of Credit Unions
P.O. Box 2982, Madison, WI 53701-2982 USA
Phone: +1-608-395-2000 | Fax: +1-608-395-2001 | 
mail@woccu.org
 | 
www.woccu.org

subject: Register with Ralph Lauren’s Supplier Diversity Partner, Supplier.io
body:
Dear RL Valued Partner,
 
We are committed to diversity, equity and inclusion (DE&I) and believe it is foundational to our business. We continuously look for opportunities to integrate DE&I into everything we do with our people, practices and how we interact and engage with our customers.
 
As part of our efforts to drive DE&I with our suppliers, Ralph Lauren has partnered with Supplier.io, which is a diverse and sustainable supplier database and discovery platform.
 
You are receiving this message because we’ve identified your company as diverse, however you are not registered as a diverse company with Supplier.io, so as a key partner to Ralph Lauren, we are asking that you officially register with Supplier.io via 
https://supplierone.co/
. Registering with Supplier.io is free of charge and could result in increased visibility as well as more business opportunities with buyers looking for new suppliers.
 
Thank you for taking the time to confirm your company’s diversity status. If you have any questions, please reach out to 
michelle.nastir@ralphlauren.com
.
 
Thank you,
RL Procurement

subject: October 2024 Issue Campaign: Food Security
body:
October 2024 Issue Campaign: Food Security
Table of Contents
Issue Brief
Organization Profile
Goalmaker Spotlight
Member Blogs
Welcome New Members
Community Events
GlobalWA Events
Careers
Dear Grace,
 
As GlobalWA’s new Executive Director, I am very excited to introduce this month’s Issue Campaign on the inspiring interventions of our members in food security. I am energized by our members and their work, and am honored to be leading this wonderful organization and supporting our vibrant community.
Almost 30 percent of the world’s population, or 2.4 billion people, are moderately or severely food insecure. Though the world is 
off track
 to achieve SDG 2 – Zero Hunger by 2030, there has been progress. The agricultural finance solutions, climate resilient practices, new mobile platforms, and other innovations illustrated below in our Issue Brief hold promise as effective and sustainable models. 
We had the pleasure of talking with Neena Joshi, Senior Vice President of Asia Programs at Heifer International, for our Goalmaker feature and learned about how cooperatives can accelerate progress for smallholder farmers. Landesa is our Organization Spotlight this month and highlights the direct relationship between land rights and food security.
Also, I look forward to meeting you at GlobalWA’s 
15th Annual Goalmaker Conference
. Our virtual day will be held on December 3 and our in-person day will be on December 4 at the Microsoft Conference Center. Be sure to register soon!
 
Sincerely,
Elizabeth Stokely,
Executive Director
 
ISSUE BRIEF
The Methods our Members are Employing to Ensure Food Security
 
Billions of people still lack access to nutritious, safe, and sufficient food. According to 
FAO
, hunger and food insecurity trends are not yet moving in the right direction to end hunger and food insecurity (SDG Target 2.1) by 2030. Yet progress is being made across many countries, and different agricultural models and practices, growing awareness and practices for developing climate resiliency, and new agricultural finance tools and reforms are proving successful. 
 
Continue ››
 
ORGANIZATION PROFILE
Landesa
 
Landesa advances pro-poor, gender-sensitive land rights reforms through law and policy tools. These reforms have helped alleviate poverty, reduce hunger, and ease conflict over land for more than 180 million families. Secure rights to land boost agricultural productivity, improve health, nutrition and school enrollment, and have placed billions of dollars in new land wealth in the hands of rural people.
Continue ››
 
GOALMAKER SPOTLIGHT
Strength in Numbers: How Neena Joshi is Elevating Asia’s Women Farmers
 
Heifer’s new Senior Vice President of Asia Programs, Neena Joshi, is used to being around strong women.
 
Born and raised in Kathmandu, Joshi says her childhood was vibrant and exciting.
 
“I was a typical city girl, that was my life,” Joshi says.
 
Continue ››
 
MEMBER BLOGS
 
Mercy Corps:
 
Nuanced and Equitable: Mercy Corps’ Approach to Food Security and the Livestock Emissions Debate
 
Opportunity International:
 
Adapting for Tomorrow: Evolving Support for Smallholders in a Changing World
 
Yemen Relief and Reconstruction Foundation:
 
Tackling Child Malnutrition in Yemen
 
World Concern:
 
Food Security & Climate Resilience on the Eroding Coast of Bangladesh
 
Global Communities:
 
Women Forward: Closing the Gender Gap in Agricultural Productivity
 
Pygmy Survival Alliance: 
How Bwiza Village Taught Us Food Security Is Job No. 1
 
Global Partnerships:
 
Investing in Access to Healthy Food
 
WELCOME NEW MEMBERS
Please welcome our newest Global Washington members. Take a moment to familiarize yourself with their work and consider opportunities for support and collaboration!
Global Impact Collective
Global Impact Collective is a design and strategy consultancy that helps organizations worldwide tackle food, health, and environmental challenges that impact life. They solve problems globally with organizations invested in changing the world. We work with companies, nonprofits, government institutions, and foundations to bring the right people together to bring about change. 
globalimpactcollective.net
 
OneWorld Health
OneWorld Health builds and operates medical facilities in East Africa and Central America using a social enterprise model to create quality, affordable healthcare solutions to communities in need. 
oneworldhealth.com/
Panorama Strategy
Panorama Strategy is a consulting firm that partners with organizations and leaders to turn their vision for social impact into a reality. Through tailored strategies, stakeholder engagement, strategic communications, and coalition building, we collaborate with our clients to identify and fulfill their unique role in creating a better world. Our certified Woman-Owned Small Business (WOSB) and agile team of people-first strategists is part of the Panorama Group, a platform for social change that has nearly 150 employees across 18 countries and a broad network of partners around the world. 
www.panoramastrategy.com/
 
Water.org
Water.org is a global nonprofit organization working to bring water and sanitation to the world. They help people get access to safe water and sanitation through affordable financing, such as small loans. 
water.org

subject: GlobalWA - Special Announcement!
body:
* SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT *
 
We are very excited to announce we have hired our next Executive Director: Elizabeth Stokely!
 
Elizabeth joins GlobalWA from Accion International, bringing over 16 years of global development experience across a variety of sectors and countries. Her extensive background in program design, strategy development and execution, and fundraising positions her as an invaluable asset to the organization. Elizabeth has a strong reputation for innovative thinking, transparent leadership, and a deep understanding of the industry landscape. 
“I am honored to join Global Washington, an organization that has been instrumental in fostering collaboration and driving interdisciplinary approaches to addressing complex global problems. I look forward to working with our dedicated members to build partnerships, spark innovation, and continue strengthening Washington State’s role in creating a more prosperous world for all.”
 
Learn more »

Upcoming GlobalWA Events
 
 
 
Q3 Final Mile Event ft. Logenix and 
Project Cure
Global Washington and Logenix are excited to host PROJECT CURE, ranked by Forbes as one of the top 20 most efficient, large US charities. With donation centers across the US, Project Cure has been a global health lifeline to communities in the US and overseas since 1987. Simply stated, Project Cure gets doctors and nurses resources they need to treat patients. Steven Wagener, the Project Cure Director of Logistics, will be our guest to present their operating model, the challenges they have faced, and how they are looking to continue to grow their impact into the future.

subject: September 2024 Special Campaign: Refugees and IDPs
body:
September 2024 Special Campaign: Refugees and IDPs
Table of Contents
Issue Brief
Organization Profile
Goalmaker Spotlight
Member Blogs
Welcome New Members
Community Events
GlobalWA Events
Careers
Dear Grace,
 
Refugees and internally displaced persons (IDPs) do not choose to leave their homes – it is an action they are forced to do. To date, nearly 120 million people have been forced to escape armed conflict, generalized violence, human rights abuses, or natural or man-made disasters.  This is a 200% increase since I began working on this issue in 2012.
 
These numbers are unprecedented and sobering. As a part Women of the World’s 2024 focus on refugees, we are publishing this Special Edition Issue Campaign on the plight of refugees and IDPs today. We have been given special permission to republish the UNHCR, The UN Refugee Agency’s Global Trends summary report while also diving into how our members, Oxfam and Global Communities, are assisting refugees in their programs. We are encouraged to hear about how our other members are helping refugees and IDPs through short summaries that are also included here.
 
 
To deeper understand the refugee experience, we encourage you to attend a free event on October 22 at the Gates Discovery Center in Seattle: 
Hope Away from Home | An Evening with Emi Mahmoud
 - a Sudanese-American slam poet, humanitarian, and UNHCR Goodwill Ambassador. We invite you to read our 
profile article
 about Emi to help you get excited about meeting this warm and dynamic former refugee.
 
 
We are also very pleased to announce we have EXTENDED our Early Bird rate for our 15th Annual Goalmakers Conference to October 15th!  The agenda and speakers will be announced in the next few days with an exciting new focus on career development for global development professionals.  We invite you to join us at this marquee event – 
register here
 today and don’t miss out on this opportunity. 
Jane Meseck
Interim Executive Director
 
ISSUE BRIEF
Refugees: Global Trends
 
When thinking about the growing global forced displacement crisis, we felt we should go directly to the experts: UNHCR, The UN Refugee Agency (USA for UNHCR is a GlobalWA member). With permission, we have republished their summary report on their latest Global Trends report, published in June 2024. You can access the full report and the data 
here
. This report, as you will see, provides key statistical trends on forced displacement, including the latest official statistics on refugees, asylum-seekers, internally displaced and stateless people, as well as the number of refugees who have returned home.
 
 
Continue ››
 
ORGANIZATION PROFILE
Oxfam – Helping Refugees Since its Inception
 
Hello, please introduce yourself, including your position(s) at Oxfam, and where you are stationed.
My name is Tara Gingerich. I am the Humanitarian Director at Oxfam America. Oxfam America is headquartered in Boston, though I live in Maine and work remotely. I have worked for Oxfam for over 15 years.

Empowering Resilience: Supporting Women and Children amid Ukraine’s Conflict

She was finishing her degree at Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv in 2022, already with the intention to work in the humanitarian field, when Russia invaded Ukraine, and everything happened faster than she thought.

subject: Venezuelan Youths Participating in Economic Inclusion Project Earn Nearly Four Times More than Peers
body:
Read on web
 | 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent to: g.vottero@lcwmail.com
 
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
2024-09-26
Venezuelan Youths Participating in Economic Inclusion Project Earn Nearly Four Times More than Peers
Study on the integration of migrants and refugees in Peru and Ecuador also shows Venezuelan women earning more than those not enrolled in EIP
 
 
Oscar Guzman presents results of the Economic Integration Study
 
Danielle Spinard speaking at an EIP event in 2023
MADISON, Wis.—Young Venezuelan refugee and migrant adults are seeing greater financial benefits than any other age group participating in the 
USAID/WOCCU Economic Inclusion Project (EIP)
, according to results from EIP’s 
Study on the Integration of Venezuelan Migrants and Refugees in Peru and Ecuador
.
The study found that while all program beneficiaries saw higher levels of income than non-EIP participants in Peru and Ecuador, Venezuelan adults aged 18 to 29 are earning $487 per month—nearly four times more than their Venezuelan peers not enrolled in the program.
Venezuelan participants aged 30 to 59 are earning just over $390 per month. Overall, EIP participants average $399 in income, compared to just $182 for Venezuelan refugees and migrants not enrolled in the program.  
“What we are seeing is that young people are taking more advantage of all the opportunities EIP has to offer, including degree revalidation, job skills training and entrepreneurship programs, and enrollment in formal financial services,” said Oscar Guzman, EIP’s Chief of Party, who presented the results during a Wednesday webinar.
Women getting ahead through EIP
With women comprising 76% of the program’s beneficiaries, the results show they are benefiting as well, earning $364 per month versus just $150 for Venezuelan women outside the program. That increased level of pay for women exceeds what men outside of the program are earning and reduces the gender income gap in Peru and Ecuador by 16%.
“One of the reasons we focused on assisting women originally was due to the structural challenges they faced in acquiring job training and launching entrepreneurial projects. EIP will continue to make further strides to level the playing field for women moving forward,” said Guzman.
“It is important to recognize that actions such as facilitating access to financial services are essential for migrants to have a stable process of economic and social integration in the host country,” said Danielle Spinard, Director of the Regional Migration and Health Office for USAID Peru, who also spoke on Wednesday’s webinar.
You can read the entire study, in Spanish, by clicking here
.
Originally launched in 2020 and renewed by USAID for three more years in 2023, the Economic Inclusion Project has assisted more than 160,000 Venezuelan migrants, refugees and local residents to improve living conditions for themselves and their families in a sustainable manner, helping them achieve integration into their host countries.
World Council of Credit Unions (WOCCU) is the apex association for credit unions and other global financial cooperatives. World Council promotes the sustainable development of credit unions and other financial cooperatives around the world to empower people through access to high quality and affordable financial services. World Council advocates on behalf of the global credit union system before international organizations and works with national governments to improve legislation and regulation. Its technical assistance programs introduce new tools and technologies to strengthen credit unions' financial performance and increase their outreach.
World Council has implemented 300+ technical assistance programs in 90 countries. Worldwide, 82,758 credit unions in 97 countries serve 404 million people. Learn more about World Council's impact around the world at 
https://url.us.m.mimecastprotect.com/s/eVZrCDkDOVil30u6UBCjLPDv?domain=woccu.org
.

Dear Grace,
As part of our dedication to fostering collaboration among credit union leaders across the globe, World Council of Credit Unions (WOCCU) continues to develop in-person and virtual learning opportunities for our members.
In response to your valuable feedback, I am very happy to introduce WOCCU Workshops—designed to provide more in-depth virtual learning experiences. 
Our inaugural workshop, "
Board Governance: Navigating Roles and Responsibilities with Management
", is scheduled for Monday, September 30, from 1:00 PM to 4:00 PM U.S. Central Daylight Time (CDT).
This workshop will equip participants with a better understanding of the distinct yet interdependent roles of credit union executives and the board directors to whom they report. Effective governance is vital for the success and sustainability of our credit unions, and a clear delineation of responsibilities is essential.
As a valued member of WOCCU, you will enjoy reduced registration rates for this workshop. I encourage you to learn more and register 
here
.
Thank you for your ongoing engagement with our networking and educational programs. Together, we can continue to strengthen the credit union movement.
Sincerely,

subject: Women’s Leadership Takes Center Stage at Asian Credit Union Forum 2024
body:
Read on web
 | 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent to: g.vottero@lcwmail.com
 
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
2024-09-12
Women’s Leadership Takes Center Stage at Asian Credit Union Forum 2024
GWLN Director Eleni Giakoumopoulos addresses closing gender gap in Bali
 
Eleni Giakoumopoulos
 
GWLN members at the Asian Credit Union Forum 2024
 
Elenita San Roque and Younsik Kim
 
MADISON, Wis.—
Global Women’s Leadership Network (GWLN)
 Director Eleni Giakoumopoulos made her first ever presentation at an Asian credit union conference by leading sessions on empowering women to become leaders at September’s Asian Credit Union Forum 2024 in Bali, Indonesia. 
Asian Confederation of Credit Unions’ (ACCU)
 CEO Elenita San Roque, who has worked to expand the reach of 
GWLN Sister Societies
 to more than 20 Asian countries and received the 2016 
Athena Leadership Award
, invited Giakoumopoulos to give a September 7 main stage presentation that focused on strategies to close the gender gap and foster inclusive leadership within the credit union sector.  
Giakoumopoulos explored practical strategies for promoting gender diversity, inclusivity and equality within credit unions to empower women leaders, emphasizing that women must make their voice heard and seize leadership opportunities to tackle barriers and change the numbers for women in leadership.  
She encouraged male leaders to engage in women's empowerment efforts by opening conversations and providing opportunities for women to thrive. 
"We are doing this not just for us today but for the next generation—our daughters, granddaughters and their children," said Giakoumopoulos. “Women are an influential force in the global economy. In line with the mission of World Council to advance financial inclusion through the credit union and cooperative model, we are committed to championing economic empowerment for women through the Global Women's Leadership Network by consciously promoting gender equity and equality. It's smart for our countries, our credit unions and our communities when we invest in women.” 
Along with her main stage presentation, Giakoumopoulos also participated in a three-day Women’s Workshop held in the days leading up to the Forum.  
Kim reelected as ACCU Board Chair 
 
ACCU reelected 
Younsik Kim
 as its Board Chair during the Forum. Kim is Chair of the National Credit Union Federation of Korea (NACUFOK) and has served as a WOCCU Board Director since 2018.  
WOCCU Board Director 
George Ombado
, who serves as Executive Director of the African Confederation of Cooperative Savings and Credit Associations (ACCOSCA), also participated in the Forum, sitting on a panel that discussed policy advocacy and regulatory frameworks, and the crucial role they play in shaping the trajectory of credit unions across the region.   
Tony
, a 2024 WOCCU Board Fellow and IT Manager for PUSKOPCUINA in Indonesia, took part in the Forum as well, moderating sessions on digital solutions for members and cybersecurity challenges facing credit unions. 
World Council of Credit Unions (WOCCU) is the apex association for credit unions and other global financial cooperatives. World Council promotes the sustainable development of credit unions and other financial cooperatives around the world to empower people through access to high quality and affordable financial services. World Council advocates on behalf of the global credit union system before international organizations and works with national governments to improve legislation and regulation. Its technical assistance programs introduce new tools and technologies to strengthen credit unions' financial performance and increase their outreach.
World Council has implemented 300+ technical assistance programs in 90 countries. Worldwide, 82,758 credit unions in 97 countries serve 404 million people. Learn more about World Council's impact around the world at

subject: GlobalWA August 2024 Issue Campaign – SDG 4: Quality Education
body:
August 2024 Issue Campaign - SDG 4: Quality Education
Table of Contents
Issue Brief
Organization Profile
Goalmaker Spotlight
Member Blogs
Community Events
 
GlobalWA Events
Careers
Dear Grace,
 
Many consider SDG 4, Quality Education to be the foundation of all the SDGs, and for good reason. Education is the path to local and global awareness, critical thinking, and self-actualization. It is a key that unlocks imagination and liberates the intellect. Through education people become empowered to create opportunity and break the cycle of poverty.
Yet, when children are kept out of school to help farm, or because of disasters, conflict or gender discrimination, it is not only the children who suffer, but the communities as well.
GlobalWA members are aware of these constant and ever-evolving challenges and lean into tried-and-true methods for creating and promoting education, and some have developed inventive solutions. 
We hope you enjoy reading about how our members are supporting SDG 4, Quality Education for all. From micro-loans to mobile schools, our members are exemplary for finding paths to provide education in the communities where they work.
And we hope you will join us on December 3-4 for our 
15th Annual Goalmakers Conference
. We are working hard to create an unforgettable experience that will educate and inspire! Early Bird tickets are available until October 1. Find out more and register here.
Jane Meseck
Interim Executive Director
 
ISSUE BRIEF
SDG 4 Quality Education
 
Sustainable Development Goal 4 states: 
Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all.
This can be at times a seemingly insurmountable task when communities need workers in the field, have gender discrimination keeping girls out of school, lack basic teaching and learning materials, or simply do not have a physical space where students and teachers can congregate for the learning experience. These challenges are global and unfortunately too common in low- and middle-income countries, especially in rural areas.
Continue ››
 
ORGANIZATION PROFILE
Global Reach, Local Impact: How Committee for Children International Expands SEL Worldwide
 
How does an organization specializing in social emotional wellbeing expand its reach to a global level?
You’d think it would take a ton of funding, resources, and people power. But sometimes all it takes to scale up is a compelling idea, the right partnerships, and a clear vision for impact.
 
Continue ››
 
GOALMAKER SPOTLIGHT
Nirmala Chaudhary, Nepal Country Director, buildOn
 
On first glance of buildOn, you may think “oh, they build schools,” which they do, and they do so much more.
buildOn has a special model where they unite communities through service and education to create positive change – and building schools are one of the wonderful and empowering outcomes.
 
Continue ››

subject: Pangea Giving Summer 2024 Update
body:
August 2024
 
Hello Pangea Community! 
 
An Exciting Season of Growth and Giving
 
The future at Pangea Giving is brighter than ever! This fall, we’re launching a brand-new grant cycle, kicking off with the much-anticipated release of our comprehensive Pangea Handbook. This guide will empower us all with the tools and knowledge needed to make an even greater impact in the communities we support.  
 
But that’s not all—November marks the start of our 
Annual Fund Drive
, a crucial time for rallying together to fuel the incredible work we do. Your passion, dedication, and generosity will drive another year of transformative change around the world.  
 
I’m thrilled to embark on this journey with you and can’t wait to see what we’ll achieve together. Let’s make this upcoming year our most impactful yet!  
 
With kind regards, 
 
Pratima Stanton 
Program Director 
Asia Pod site visit. Photo: Emily Cho
POD UPDATES
We’re delighted to share some exciting updates with you since our last communication in February. In March, we successfully concluded another impactful grant cycle, awarding 
$118,000 to 17 partners
 across Southeast Asia, Latin America, and East Africa. For more details, you can explore the full story 
here
. 
 
Site Visits:
 Site visits are in full swing this year. Last February, our Asia Pod conducted a site visit (see more below), and looking ahead, our Latin America Pod is preparing for a site visit to Guatemala this October. We anticipate another enriching experience.  
LA Pod:
 LA Pod members are evaluating potential new grant partners, planning the upcoming Guatemala site visit, and have been receiving updates on progress from several of the grant partners. For detailed updates on the LA Pod, go 
here
.  
Africa Pod:
 The East Africa Leadership Forum (ELAF) had their 2024 gathering which resulted in some wonderful insights and forward-thinking recommendations. Read their report 
here
. 
Asia Pod:
 Through their site visit in February 2024, they were able to affirm their grant dollars are truly making an impact. They were also introduced to some new potential grant partners! You can read their insightful report 
here
. 
 
MEMBER UPDATES
In addition to our grantmaking efforts, we’re pleased to welcome new members 
Shawn 
and 
Lynne Aebi
, 
Jane Meseck 
and 
Lisa Basu
, who have joined us over the past year. Our member renewal drives are progressing smoothly, and we’re on track to meet our goals. A heartfelt thank you to everyone who has renewed their membership—we look forward to another successful year together! 
 
Interested in Pangea Giving membership?
 Join 
here
.
Shawn and Lynne Aebi
Shawn spent his career in technology and has volunteered with organizations such as Habitat for Humanity, Hopelink, 501 commons, and Team Rubicon. Shawn continues to volunteer his skill and expertise in IT along with aiding at food banks and disaster response projects. He gets his hands dirty in trail work parties with Washington Trails Association and Global Village Builds in Indonesia, Guatemala, and Paraguay with Habitat for Humanity. Shawn has a Bachelor of Science focused on Mathematics from Georgia Institute of Technology.  
Lynne’s professional background includes eight years with the U.S. government as a global economic analysts and two years as an Executive Director at the Northwest Entrepreneur Network. For the past 12 years, Lynne has been the owner of Yoga4Life and a certified yoga and meditation teacher, which includes work as a nature therapy guide. Lynne has a BA in Political Science from Berkeley and an MA in International Affairs from George Washington.   
Jane Meseck
Jane has served the nonprofit and humanitarian sectors for 30 years. Formerly Sr. Director for Microsoft Philanthropies, Jane was a leader in Microsoft’s social impact work and led programs and partnerships supporting international humanitarian organizations and the communities they serve, respond, and rebuild from crisis. Jane has been a fixture in the nonprofit tech segment, leading Microsoft’s effort to help nonprofits and humanitarian organizations adopt and use technology for mission. She led Microsoft technology donations for over 20 years scaling donations to 235 countries and $1B FMV. She helped create NTEN and supported TechSoup’s growth as the premier global online nonprofit resource. In 2017, Jane helped create Microsoft’s Tech for Social Impact team bringing together the best of Microsoft’s commercial ecosystem with renowned philanthropy programs. In July 2020, Jane formed a new Philanthropies’ team to help expand humanitarian efforts to empower humanitarian organizations and crisis affected communities through technology, including AI for Humanitarian Action. Jane currently serves on the Board of Directors of USA for UNHCR and GlobalWA, continuing her personal mission to support humanitarian and global development nonprofits.  
Lisa Basu
Lisa has worked in the international development sector for over ten years, primarily focused on monitoring, evaluation, and learning across a range of sectors, with an emphasis on gender and inclusive development, rural development, and human rights. Lisa currently works as a Senior Program Manager at Social Impact, where she oversees a diverse portfolio of evaluation and learning contracts for clients, including USAID, DOS, and private foundations. Before working at Social Impact, Lisa lived, worked, and conducted research across southeast Asia for four years, primarily based in Laos. Lisa has a BA in Global Development Studies from Seattle Pacific University and an MA in International Development and Social Change from Clark University. 
 
STAFF UPDATES
We’re excited to welcome 
Megan Chao
 as our new Operations Manager, where she will oversee GlobalWA and Pangea’s financial operations. Teaming up with our Communications Director, 
Joel Meyers
, who oversees all Pangea public communications, Megan is already making a notable impact on our team’s success. Meanwhile, the search for a new Executive Director is progressing well, and we look forward to announcing our selected candidate very soon.  
Megan Chao, Operations Manager, GlobalWA
Megan has over 15 years of experience in global development specializing in youth empowerment, community-centric fundraising, and nonprofit operations. Prior to Global Washington, she was the US Executive Director and Co-Founder of Hope for Life, an international nonprofit focused on empowering youth to escape homelessness in East Africa through trauma-informed and family centered programming.
Megan holds a Bachelor’s Degree in Psychology and Certificates in Nonprofit Management and Bookkeeping. She is passionate about equity, equipping local leadership, and nonprofit collaboration to solve systemic issues. Outside of work, she enjoys playing and coaching volleyball, reading, and traveling.

subject: July 2024 Issue Campaign – SDG 6: Clean Water and Sanitation
body:
July 2024 – SDG 6: Clean Water and Sanitation
Table of Contents
Issue Brief
Organization Profile
Goalmaker Spotlight
Member Blogs
Welcome New Members
Community Events
Careers
Dear Grace,
 
Unsafe water, inadequate sanitation, and insufficient hygiene kill 3.5 million people every year, and water scarcity affects more than 40% of the global population. These are staggering numbers, yet GlobalWA members show an amazing amount of ingenuity and resourcefulness when it comes to ensuring WASH in the communities where they work.
In our Issue Brief you will read about how our members have created key partnerships, innovative solutions, and strong monetary commitments to ensure safe water, appropriate hygiene, and innovative waste and sanitation solutions in low- and middle-income communities.
Included are also articles about a key partnership between World Vision and Rotary International safeguarding water for communities in Ethiopia, as well as a revealing interview with a Ugandan WASH expert from The Hunger Project.
GlobalWA members illustrate amazing adaptive solutions in the face of climate change, growing and shifting populations, and the need for new innovations. We hope you will be as inspired as we are!
Jane Meseck
Interim Executive Director
 
ISSUE BRIEF
Closing the Resource Gap: How Clean Water Changes Lives
 
Members at Global Washington take innovative steps to address the global water crisis. Communities impacted by a lack of access to clean drinking water, proper sanitation infrastructure or an awareness of healthy sanitary practices, are facing disease, malnourishment and problems in other sectors, spilling into education and local markets. To that end, organizations are bringing unique solutions that address the crisis at multiple levels of operation, closing the gap between clean water and at-risk communities. 
Continue ››
 
ORGANIZATION PROFILE
Joint Interventions for Ethiopia’s Water Crisis: World Vision partners with the Rotary Foundation
 
Facing the fallout of ongoing armed conflict, impending natural disaster and subsequent resource scarcity is Ethiopia, ranking at 9 out of the top 10 most at-risk countries for humanitarian emergencies on the Independent Rescue Committee’s 
2024 Emergency Watchlist
. From a three-year drought to overbearing floods in vulnerable regions, rampant food and water insecurity is projected to be on the rise, driven by military tensions and an influx of displaced persons from neighboring states. In Ethiopia, and across Somalia, Kenya, Djibouti and Eretria, an estimated 
20 million people
 are predicted to be in dire need of food and water assistance by UNICEF.  
Continue ››
 
GOALMAKER SPOTLIGHT
Ibrahim Ogaram, Food Security and Nutrition Officer, The Hunger Project Uganda
 
The Hunger Project (THP), a GlobalWA member since 2018, was founded in 1977 with the goal of ending world hunger. They have ongoing programs in Africa, Asia, and Latin America aimed at mobilizing rural grassroots communities to achieve sustainable progress in health, education, nutrition, and family income. WASH is one of those activities and it is one of the foundations for community health.
Continue ››
 
MEMBER BLOGS
 
GREDO
 
Delivering Sustainable Water Solutions in Somalia: GREDO’s Holistic Approach
 
Yemen Relief and Reconstruction Foundation
 
Hope in Every Drop: Bringing Clean Water to Yemen
 
WELCOME NEW MEMBERS
Please welcome our newest Global Washington members. Take a moment to familiarize yourself with their work and consider opportunities for support and collaboration!
Stronger Stories
Stronger Stories is a social enterprise that helps good ideas get the support they deserve. Combining story science with expert coaching/consultancy, Stronger Stories supports organizations and social entrepreneurs dedicated to solving systemic issues. Free tools and online learning to democratize storytelling power are available at 
strongerstories.org
.

subject: June 2024 Issue Campaign – Decent Work – SDG 1 and SDG 8
body:
June 2024 – Decent Work – SDG 1 and SDG 8
Table of Contents
Issue Brief
Organization Profile
Goalmaker Spotlight
Member Blogs
Community Events
Careers
Dear Grace,
 
In this month’s Issue Brief we deep dive into how our members are addressing SDG 1 “No Poverty” and SDG 8 “Decent Work and Economic Growth,” with a specific eye on how members are leveraging new technologies (such as AI), digital skills development, closing the gender work gap, and creating new opportunities in this ever-changing landscape of technological change.
To understand the evolving workforce challenges, we talked with Ama Akuamoah, Director of Market Engagement of the Digital Innovation Group at Opportunity International who has direct on-the-ground involvement delivering solutions to final-mile communities. We also had a revealing conversation with Naria Santa Lucia, General Manager of Digital Inclusion at Microsoft Philanthropies who talked about the importance of upskilling communities with digital technologies, services, and products to ensure no one is left behind. 
The programs and interventions GlobalWA members are implementing in communities where they work are exemplifying a new standard and are setting a hopeful course for current and future generations.
Jane Meseck
Interim Executive Director
 
ISSUE BRIEF
The Future of Work
 
The very first Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) is “No Poverty.” It’s so important that SDG 8 further expands to cover “Decent Work and Economic Growth” – key factors in pulling people out of poverty. Decent work is the cornerstone of a thriving society, ensuring dignity, security, and fulfillment for individuals, while driving economic prosperity. In the rapidly evolving landscape of the future of work, digital skills are becoming increasingly crucial to stay competitive and adaptable. They unlock new opportunities all over the world and enable access to remote work and flexible employment, promoting inclusivity and work-life balance. By investing in digital skills development, GlobalWA members are fostering sustainable growth and resilience in the face of technological change.  
Continue ››
 
ORGANIZATION PROFILE
Stronger Tomorrow: Integral Efforts by Microsoft to Build Digital Capacities and Technological Proficiency
 
In October, 2023, 
Microsoft
 partnered with 
M-PESA Africa
 in 
Nairobi
 to strengthen their efforts in digitizing small and medium-sized enterprises in various markets, and introducing businesses to digital skills training programs on the 
Microsoft Community Platform
. Helping businesses become more comfortable with modern technologies and learning to use them may be the key to building resilience in rapidly transforming economies, and ensuring longevity and adaptability for enterprises of any scale. By partnering with local NGOs in targeted communities, Microsoft’s digital upskilling programs can be modified for a variety of local contexts, requirements, and problems – something that generative AI is becoming increasingly useful for. 
Continue ››
 
GOALMAKER SPOTLIGHT
Ama Akuamoah, Director of Market Engagement, Digital Innovation Group, Opportunity International
 
“The economic empowerment of a woman is the economic empowerment of a family and the communities that make up a nation.”
 
This powerful observation was shared with me by Ama Akuamoah, the Director of Market Engagement for the Digital Innovation Group at 
Opportunity International
. I was able to connect with her while she was in Malawi, having recently visited some final-mile project locations there. We had a wonderful conversation over Zoom. She was relaxed, perhaps a bit tired being that it was the end of her (busy) day, and had a wonderful, attentive demeanor, and an infectious smile! 
Continue ››

subject: WFCU Webinar - Ukraine's Credit Unions: Two Years Later
body:
Read on web
 | 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent to: g.vottero@lcwmail.com
 
Ukraine's Credit Unions: Two Years Later
Wednesday, June 26, 10:00 a.m. U.S. Central Daylight Time (CDT)
When many financial institutions retreat during times of crisis, credit unions worldwide keep their doors open—serving members and communities as financial first responders during times of greatest need.
Project Storm Break
, Worldwide Foundation for Credit Union’s (WFCU) disaster relief initiative, has been a major source of assistance for the international credit union system, distributing more than $3 million in relief and resiliency aid since 2010.
This informational webinar will feature Project Storm Break staff and grant beneficiaries sharing both success stories and updates on one of Project Storm Break's most impactful grant programs to date, in Ukraine, by:
Articulating the needs of Ukraine’s credit unions in year three of Russia’s full-scale invasion of the country.
Sharing the impact of WFCU’s Ukrainian Credit Union Displacement Fund, which has raised more than $1.8 million for credit union grant programs since February 2022.
Providing an overview of Project Storm Break, its grant qualifications, processes and current programs.
This webinar will feature presentations from:
Mike Reuter
, President, WFCU (USA)
Viacheslav Vytiuk
, CEO, PVKS Credit Union (Ukraine)
Alisa Stetsyshyn, 
Grant Management Consultant, WFCU (Ukraine)
For questions about this webinar, contact Alisa Stetsyshyn at 
astetsyshyn@woccu.org
.

Are you ready to

When we say Gala, we actually mean party… so maybe it’s an un-Gala!
  
Your peers are going to have a

subject: Webinar: ATM Crime: It's What You Don't Know That Can Hurt You
body:
Read on web
 | 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent to: g.vottero@lcwmail.com
 
ATM Crime: It's What You Don't Know That Can Hurt You
Tuesday, June 11th at 10:00am CT
Esta sesión también estará disponible en español.
According to data from Pinkerton, ATM crime increased 600% from 2019 -2021, influenced by the pandemic.  
Lowers Risk Group data shows a 165% increase year over year from 2021 – 2022. 
ABA Insurance Services recorded a five-fold increase in the number ATM crime claims from 2020 to 2022. 
And we know the trend continues today.  No segment of the ATM industry is escaping unharmed. 
David Tente, will highlight current trends in ATM crime and discuss the importance of staying informed about current and local criminal activity.  Criminal activity is not homogenous – the same from state to state or region to region. 
No ATM deployer likes being connected to an ATM crime of any kind.  But trying to hide from the current reality actually makes matters worse.  You need to know what your peers are experiencing – and they need to know yours.
 
This session is presented by:
David Tente
Executive Director, USA & Americas
ATMIA (the ATM Industry Association)
World Council will be offering CPE Credits for this webinar! Participants must be present for the full session to receive credit. Attendance will be recorded. There is no fee to attend!
Participants will earn 1.0 CPE Credit.

subject: Crack out of your shell at WCUC!
body:
Read this in your browser.
Are you ready to 
crack out of your shell 
at WCUC in Boston?
  
When we say Gala, we actually mean party… so maybe it’s an un-Gala!
  
Your peers are going to have a 
claw-some
 time at 
WFCU’s Gala at Thompson Island
, and we want you to party with us!
The Gala at Thompson Island is the credit union event of the year that you don’t want to 
risk
 missing. We’ll have lobsters for everyone, drinks abound and plenty of fun to go around.
After the DJ gets the party started on the boat ride, grab a drink and a seat to start 
clawing
 into some delicious lobster.
Need some more excitement in one night? How about entertainment performing all your favorites!
Straight from New England, our DJ will 
rock your claws off
 with a night of jams and dancing.
For a dancing break, we’ll have classic American yard games and a bonfire to cap the night.
We can’t wait to see you in Boston.
Please RSVP by July 8, 2024.

subject: Nominations Open for Second Annual WOCCU Fellowship
body:

Learn why this is important
Read on web

Unsubscribe
